same power laws as in the decaying case are realized for an infinite system.

We consider asymptotics of the velocity derivatives probability distribution functions (PDFs) in
Burgers' turbulence. We argue that in the forced case the same power laws as in the decaying case
are realized for an infinite system.
PACS numbers: 47.27.Gs, 02.50.Ey, 05.60.-k

non-linear one-dimensional acoustic waves in the reference frame moving with the sound velocity [1]. The equation is written for the velocity u

Recently statistical properties of solutions of the Burgers equation (1) have attracted a considerable attention,
since it is a simple model which could demonstrate some
features of developed turbulence [2]. Then one assumes a
large value of the Reynolds number Re = V L/ν, where V
and L are characteristic velocity and length of the largescale motion. One can treat decaying (f = 0) or forced
turbulence. In the decaying case statistics of u is timedependent, whereas it is expected to be stationary, if the
pumping force f is a process statistically homogeneous
in space and time. We consider both possibilities.
An object, mainly treated in papers devoted to Burgers
turbulence, is the PDF P1 (ξ) of the velocity derivative
ξ = u′ . This PDF is strongly asymmetric. The right tail
of the PDF decays fast in accordance with the inviscid
law ln P1 ∝ −ξ 3 [3–5]. The inviscid left tail entailed a
controversy. Different values of the exponent α for this
tail P1 ∝ |ξ|−α were proposed in the works [4,6–11], see
also the discussion in [12,13]. Below we confirm the validity of the answer α = 7/2, claimed in [9,11], for the
forced case in an infinite system.

Now we proceed to investigating the forced Burgers
turbulence. We consider the force f continuously distributed over time and space and having a homogeneous
statistics. Then the statistics of ξn is also homogeneous
in time. We assume that f is smooth both in space and
time.
As previously, we are interested in vicinities of the
shock formation points. Let us consider a prehistory
of the u evolution during the time t before the shock
creation point, where L/V ≫ t ≫ |ξ|−1 . The first inequality enables one to neglect the pumping force during
the evolution. The second condition ensures the validity
of the expansion (3) for examining the shock formation.
Thus, we return to the expression (5), where P(σ, s) is

u′ < 0, u′′′ > 0, this PDF is stationary in the pumping
case. However, there is a problem related to an explicit
dependence of the answer on the auxiliary time t. Let us
demonstrate, that such dependence is really absent.
